fields.trailText: In this week's edition, CIA whistleblower Edward Snowden speaks out, Paul Lester meets the band who laid the foundations of heavy metal, Black Sabbath, and this week's audiobook review celebrates 100 years since DH Lawrence published Sons and Lovers, and charts a very different relationship between a mother and her son in Melvyn Bragg's latest novel, Grace and Mary.

tags.bio: Paul Lester been contributing to the Guardian for most of this century. Among other things, he writes the new band of the day feature for guardian.co.uk's music site
Simon Goodley is a business reporter

Alok Jha is a science correspondent at the Guardian. In addition to writing news and comment, he presents the Science Weekly podcast. A physics graduate from Imperial College London, he has been at the Guardian since the launch of the science supplement, Life, in 2003. He is the author of The Doomsday Handbook: 50 Ways to the End of the World and How To Live Forever And 34 Other Really Interesting Uses for Science, both published by Quercus. You can find him on Twitter at @alokjha and his personal website is at alokjha.com

Glenn Greenwald is a columnist on civil liberties and US national security issues for the Guardian. A former constitutional lawyer, he was until 2012 a contributing writer at Salon. He is the author of How Would a Patriot Act? (May 2006), a
critique of the Bush administration's use of executive power; A
Tragic Legacy (June, 2007), which examines the Bush legacy; and With Liberty and Justice For Some: How the Law Is Used to Destroy Equality and Protect the Powerful
Ewen MacAskill is the Guardian's Washington DC bureau chief. He was diplomatic editor from 1999-2006, chief political correspondent from 1996-99 and political editor of the Scotsman from 1990-96

webTitle: Britain's last wilderness: Scotland's Knoydart peninsula - video

fields.standfirst: The Knoydart peninsula, on Scotland's north-west coast, is shaped by its remoteness and accessible only by boat or on foot – but it is a thriving, tight-knit community with a strong connection to the land and sea. The spirit of the place is reflected in its two restaurants, The Old Forge and Doune, which both pride themselves on the fresh seafood caught in the surrounding waters. This video, made in association with Wilderness Scotland, serves up a slice of local life

webTitle: How many more prisoners have to die in custody? | Eric Allison

fields.standfirst: The failure of the prison service to learn from its mistakes means there will be more avoidable deaths in custody
fields.trailText: Eric Allison: The failure of the prison service to learn from its mistakes means there will be more avoidable deaths in custody
fields.headline: How many more prisoners have to die in custody?

tags.bio:
Eric Allison is the Guardian's prison correspondent.

He was born in Manchester, 1942, the youngest of four boys. His first conviction was for housebreaking when he was 11 and, at 14, he received his first custodial sentence. Three months in a detention centre was intended to provide a "short sharp shock" to deter him but instead he met up with virtually every member of the "class of 57" during his criminal/penal journey, which ended in 2000. Eric Allison has spent some 16 years in prison, all for theft related offences. During that time he quickly became appalled at the bad treatment handed out to people who had not "chosen" crime as a career and witnessed acts of brutality and racism on an almost daily basis. As a result he decided to speak out and took action against the abuse. He discovered that the adage "the pen is mightier … " proved particularly accurate in prison and, following the Strangeways Prison Riot, in 1990, he co-authored a book on the protest, A Serious Disturbance. The book was used by several education authorities as A-level course work (Sociology). In 2003 Eric Allison joined the Guardian as the prison correspondent.

webTitle: Emil and the Detectives: watch a clip from the long-lost British remake of Erich Kästner's childrens' story - video

fields.standfirst:
Watch a clip from the British-made adaptation of Erich Kästner's popular story about a boy who retrieves his stolen pocket money with the help of a young gang known as the Detectives. Set in London, and directed by Milton Rosmer, it was thought lost for many years, until it was sighted recently at a small film festival in the US. It's a remake of a well-known German film from 1931, directed by Gerhard Lamprecht and written by Kästner, Billy Wilder and an uncredited Emeric Pressburger.

• Emil and the Detectives is released by the BFI on DVD on 15 June, and features both the German and British versions

webTitle: Guardian Camera Club: Sean Gaule's portfolio

fields.standfirst:
A review of Sean Gaule's portfolio.

The light, composition and even the vapour trail of 'Abandoned shack' combine to make a resonant image that tells its story. That snaking line of the sculpture installation in 'Water of Leith sculpture', leading into a foggy background is another perfect and atmospheric composition. The next image named 'The shore disappearing' is a foggy, soft black & white landscape, the striding figure looking oddly out of place. Monochromatic colour (and more fog) makes 'Holyrood' a pictorial image, the figure a distant subject; 'Towers - water' is a great New York view, the ever present fog adding to the low contrast tonality. Back to stronger light with 'Stilted box', where the waiting man adds another element
fields.headline: Guardian Camera Club: Sean Gaule's portfolio
fields.trailText: A review of Sean Gaule's portfolio
